displayed_text: Patient: Many years ago. Doctor: And because it’s one kidney and you know whether the enzalutamide is doing anything, the protein, the diabetes, the losartan, the hypertension it all (noise) Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …and that’s just way too hard for me to keep up. I can only focus in on your prostate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m now going to send you to the expert. So if it’s not him then somebody else over will be fine. They’re all really good. Patient: Yeah we’ll get - What’s the, what’s the group that he’s in? Doctor: I think it’s really like B______ Nephrology. There’s only one big group there. Family Member: Okay. Patient: M___ Kidney Consultants. Oh, okay. Doctor: Yeah and they may be called that. Yep. Patient: And yeah, yeah that must be because that’s their office in R___ and T___...

Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And so those are all issues that you’ve got to sort out. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: How do you know it’s working? Family Member: I think that we should probably wait until catheter is out. Patient: Right, that’s what I was thinking originally, Family Member: And see what happens with medication. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um, now about the uh hormone shots. So he’s covered for three months. After that expires he should get another shot and you start chemo? Doctor: He will have another shot, so it should be in here already. I will put it in. Family Member: In January.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: It’s being done for die- his diabetic condition. Doctor: Right. Patient: Yeah. So how do I counter that? Doctor: That’s where you have to go to a nephrologist ‘cause they’re smarter than me. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: They gotta work with the kidney and in your case it really is the kidney. Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: Um and it just depends on where you want to see this person. I’m – Do you see the B______ docs? Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Yep. Are a R____ or T____?

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the reason I’m mentioning that is because a lot of patients do want to go on this therapy without being on the Lupron at the same time or a similar drug. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And the way that the trial is designed, if you give the testosterone without concurrently at the same time, suppressing the testosterone as well, then you don’t achieve these opposites between very high and very low levels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: What happens is over time is the testosterone just keeps increasing and increasing and increasing, and eventually it will begin to feed the cancer, at least in theory. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological.

Family Member: Ohh. Okay. Doctor: Don’t quote me. Patient: So I only have to come down once every three weeks? Yeah. Family Member: So what's the difference between the trial infusion timetable and the infusion of just getting the infusions. Doctor: None. It's still once every three weeks. Family Member: Yeah, there's no difference? Doctor: There's no difference. So it's just if you get on the study arm and you get the pill chemo version, then you might have a slightly different schedule. And I should know all that except I rely heavily on my research nurse to make sure that's right. Because they change the schedule sometimes so often, and I'm just gonna so ask S____ to help me. Family Member: Yeah guess the question I have is, what if for some reason the roads are really bad, the weather’s really bad? Are you flexible? Doctor: Oh, we would just reschedule. Oh, yes. We would never put you at risk for safety. If let's say you're just sick with something, it's not cancer related. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You don't come down. You got to do this hard thing. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes we have to be a little bit off cycle because, again, the weather for us is usually the big thing.

Family Member: Oh. Doctor: It looked like they should be in a catalog. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So, I wasn’t sure if it was like Tigers day or. Family Member: I know. Yes. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Just working zone. (Laughter) Doctor: How you feeling? Patient: I’ve been great. Doctor: The rest of your labs are fine, but, you know, your PSA is trickling up, four point two. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Now, in March, you were at two and a half. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: So they don’t die… Doctor: Correct. Patient: I see oh yeah, yeah, yeah we’re still on that. Doctor: This is a shot that’s - why that shot is important is just because it’s just a one time and then it’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But the alternative cheaper version of that is a daily shot to keep your cells up. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know, I’m sorry. Patient: And you would recommend that at least at a minimum? Doctor: Well, you know there’s two ways to approach this. We could wait until you really are in trouble. And in trouble would mean you have a fever, you have no white cells, you better come in to the hospital, you need antibiotics. Patient: Yeah I don’t know (stammering) Doctor: But you’ve already demonstrated that your cells go down. You know you weren’t doing great. I just think we’re asking for trouble. So I’ve tried to explain that and they’re like is it a fever with no white cells. That’s all the understand. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yes. And then, of course, you know, we do do this, and I really want you to consider, you know, donating the extra bloods as we go throughout the year because I get to follow you for this whole time anyways. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So it’s not like you have to come back, and he’s, it’s just when you come back, when we stick you, we can get up to like ten extra tubes of blood because it’s that much we have to check. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Your immune system is really complicated. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we have to check everything. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah. So there’s no sticking or biopsies but it’s a blood draw. And you have lots to spare. So don’t say, “Oh, my, God”. Doctor: “She can take this ten and that’s it. I’m rolling out of here.” No. You have lots, and lots, and lots of blood to donate. Okay? Family Member: Oh, okay.

Patient: Well, I just work this job. (Laughter) Doctor: The job has exercise? Patient: Oh, my, God. That’s exercise right there, but, uh, you know. Doctor: You’re eating a low, low-fat and high-fiber diet? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So you’re doing all the right things. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, uh, we’ll continue to follow you closely, like every six months. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you have any problems before that time, give us a call. Patient: Um hum. Because I don’t feel, I don’t feel sickly or anything like that. You know? Doctor: Alright. That’s good.

Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: What’s your name? Family Member: K___ P____. He probably wouldn’t remember me. Doctor: I don’t know, he sometimes tends to remember a lot of the people he did… Family Member: Is he still in radiation oncology here? Doctor: He is. He just started back here within the last year. Before that he was at other hospitals. Family Member: Uh huh. Doctor: So yeah. Family Member: That’s great. Doctor: Alright. Family Member: Thank you, thank you again. Doctor: That is amazing. Small world right. Family Member: Yeah. (Laughs)

Patient: You are? Doctor: Yeah. Why have it be a mystery. Because if you do call me, guess what I’m gonna say? Hey Mr. you need to get an x-ray. So I’m gonna bypass that question… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …and we’re just gonna see what it is. Patient: So you’re, you’re thinking Doctor: Yeah. Patient: it I mean an x-ray to look at it that may be even a replacement here or something’s been compromised here or the cancer side? Doctor: Well yeah or if it’s just arthritis then we often just… Patient: I see. Doctor: … we can all just be happy or Patient: Okay. Doctor: At some point you’ll probably get a knee-hip replacement.

Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it? Doctor: V as in Victor. Patient: Oh ARV7 and thought that you know there were some possibilities there. The liver pathology at Hospital B he wasn’t real keen on and so he had the samples sent up here. Doctor: And they confirmed that it’s prostate cancer. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, rather than liver cancer, yes, and that’s kind of where we stand. Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say. Doctor: Okay, well my sense is you know he and I can talk about sort of when’s the right time to get new pictures, and the lung stuff is interesting because is it just cancer in your lung that causing this gasping, this wheezing? Patient: He doesn’t think so. Doctor: I don’t think so either, but you’d have to rule that out because that can complicate sometimes clinical trials- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because using experimental therapies in somebody who’s got something else going wrong that’s not the cancer or the therapy- Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Family Member: …and they cauterized. Doctor: the radiation and it’s cauterized now so I’m thinking that will take care of it. Patient: Yet no polyps, no polyps. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, good. Healthcare Professional: And their advice to hold up on aspirin. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I got to talk to the heart doctor now because he has me on the aspirin and the… Family Member: Unless you think… Patient: The tush doctor told me no aspirin. Doctor: Don’t take it until – but that could probably be temporary as long as the bleeding has stopped you know if a few weeks they may be able to go ahead and restart. Family Member: So would we be completely transferring care downtown then? Doctor: For?

Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: But, it’s usually letters and numbers. Ummm. But, they work in a class of drugs that we think are highly active in prostate cancer, so it’s about five different drugs that are in this space, targeting the same pathway. So, we just don’t know which one has an opening. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And, when would that start? Doctor: M___ will tell us, but probably, you know, obviously in the new year, and it maybe second or third week… Patient: Well, they took seven vials of blood… Doctor: Yes, we did! Patient: Three of them are staying here… Doctor: Mm-hmm. Patient: And we should get the results shortly. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And the other four were going back to the lab, or to the ….

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Previously, we’ve been letting people stay on the testosterone. They feel good plus their scans don’t look any worse. I think given that your PSA went up, you’re feeling good, and the scans are a little worse, maybe you should come off it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And think about what’s next. Patient: Yeah. What is next? Doctor: Yeah. That’s the hard part of the day. Uh well I guess the first question is you sort of came here specifically for this. Are you going to, do you want to stay here for the next or is the next, do you want to go somewhere, to shop around? Patient: No, no. I, I came here because Dr. T___ out at S__ say, say, oh, you know, certainly recommended it. I guess he’s part of this study too, so. Doctor: He is. He is. Patient: So uh he felt pretty strongly that coming here to participate but also to, to say here is- Doctor: Remind me again how you hooked up with him. Patient: Yeah. Through the urologist that I had that did the surgery. Doctor: Because you’re mostly east coast. You, you moved?
